data.title: Sourcemap files in subfolders are ignored
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.8.0-insider (dbf3ba74e6cf3b33687b7d47e321e642fc1e7562)
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.1

I'm trying to add debugging support to one of our Node projects but VS Code is having trouble finding the sourcemaps of `.js` files that are located in subfolders of my `dist` directory. The `dist` directory mirrors the hierarchy structure of my `src` directory.

This is what my `gulp` task looks like:
```javascript
gulp.task('build-ts', function () {
  let tsResult = gulp.src(['src/**/*.ts', 'typings/**/*.d.ts'])
    .pipe(sourcemaps.init())
    .pipe(tsProject());

  return tsResult.js
    .pipe(sourcemaps.write())
    .pipe(gulp.dest('dist'));
});
```

And this is my `launch.json`:
```json
{
  "name": "Launch Program",
  "type": "node",
  "console": "integratedTerminal",
  "request": "launch",
  "program": "${workspaceRoot}/src/index.ts",
  "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
  "runtimeArgs": [
    "--nolazy"
  ],
  "args": [
    "login"
  ],
  "outFiles": ["${workspaceRoot}/dist/**/*.js"],
  "sourceMaps": true,
  "preLaunchTask": "build"
}
```

While I can easily set a breakpoint in my `src/index.ts` file, everything that is in a file that is not in the root directory of `src` or `dist` respectively does not work. Am I using `outFiles` wrong?
My problem feels kind of similar to https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/13499 but none of the suggested solutions there solved my issue.
Is there anything I can provide to help diagnose/troubleshoot this? Thanks!

data.title: Linux: Command palette disagree with shortcuts behaviour
data.body:
Hi. I don't know if it's related only to my locale and keyboard, to Linux with a keyboard layout different from US or if it's related to #713. I apologize in advance because I haven't known find it.
According to the command palette and the keybinding widget, I get some shortcuts with a different behaviour regarding I use it. This affects to shortcuts with symbols like slash, plus, minus,..

My system:

- VSCode Version: 1.6.1 and 1.7.1
- OS Version: Fedora 24 (Linux 4.7.6-200 x86_64)

```
$ locale
LANG=es_ES.UTF-8
LC_CTYPE="es_ES.UTF-8"
LC_NUMERIC="es_ES.UTF-8"
LC_TIME="es_ES.UTF-8"
LC_COLLATE="es_ES.UTF-8"
LC_MONETARY="es_ES.UTF-8"
LC_MESSAGES="es_ES.UTF-8"
LC_PAPER="es_ES.UTF-8"
LC_NAME="es_ES.UTF-8"
LC_ADDRESS="es_ES.UTF-8"
LC_TELEPHONE="es_ES.UTF-8"
LC_MEASUREMENT="es_ES.UTF-8"
LC_IDENTIFICATION="es_ES.UTF-8"
LC_ALL=
```
```
$ setxkbmap -query
rules:      evdev
model:      pc105
layout:     es,es
variant:    ,
options:    compose:rctrl
```

Keyboard like this:
![Spanish KB](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/243047/20006354/6791b778-a297-11e6-9884-f5b2552244ae.png)

Steps to Reproduce (toggle comment, for example):

1. `Ctrl` + `Shift` + `P` to look for _Toggle Line Comment_.
![Looking for command](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/243047/20005908/3b77c166-a295-11e6-8042-b0a82cb60dc2.png)
Or I look for it in the keybinding settings file:
![kb settings](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/243047/20006595/8ec589cc-a298-11e6-9767-2d11fdb184a9.png)
2. According to the suggestion, I push `Ctrl` + `-` (next to right shift key) but the font size is reduced. I don't get the toggle line comment action.
3. If I push `Ctrl` + `-` (minus sign from numpad) I get nothing.
4. If I push `Ctrl` + `ç` I get the toggle line coment.
5. I check `Ctrl` + `k` `Ctrl` + `ç` and I get this is detected like `Ctrl` + `k` `Ctrl` + `-`
![Check keybinding](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/243047/20006194/c7f135d6-a296-11e6-9e0f-b10d94654fd4.png)

I get a similar behaviour with _Toggle Integrated Terminal_ and _Split Editor_:

![integrated terminal](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/243047/20006669/eedf8b28-a298-11e6-93c7-8bfe0cc7a33d.png)
I push `Ctrl` + `º` but I get the _Split Editor_ action.

![split editor](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/243047/20006718/2b2273ca-a299-11e6-8f6a-6655f7e86b39.png)
I push `Ctrl` + `ç` but I get the _Toggle Line Comment_ action
![comment line](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/243047/20006756/4f4d167e-a299-11e6-9ac4-be88ece244e0.png)

Do you know this behaviour?

data.title: Format Code: func-call-spacing error?
data.body:
I have an Angular controller which is wrapped in an IIFE.  When I use VSCode's "format code" command, it adds a space between the function and parens, which is correct:

`_this.deploy = function () {...}`

But "format code" does this to the end of the IIFE, which is equally ok but eslint flags it as an error:

![screen shot 2016-11-03 at 10 54 56 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/835148/19971303/03256204-a1b5-11e6-8918-e2ee8610e8f3.jpg)

Can this be remedied via settings, or is this a bug?

data.title: Up Arrow doesn't work using Code Folding
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8 insiders
- OS Version: Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a typescript file
2. Fold any piece of code
3. Press down button (works fine)
4. Press up button.
**Expected:** Works as always
**Actual:** Cursor moves strangely depending on the position in the file and the structure of folded code. It might hop between folded sections or just move down a line or do almost anything but go up.

data.title: Docs: Add Cygwin terminal
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Win10

With the new command line options for Windows integrated terminal, it now is finally possible to start a proper working Cygwin terminal in the current project. GREAT!

For that you need to have base Cygwin and the `chere` package installed. There is not need to run the chere command and integrate Cygwin with your Explorer. The chere package is just needed for the `/bin/xhere` command that comes with it.

When you only use `C:\\Cygwin\\bin\\bash.exe` (so without these command line options) the Cygwin path is not set properly and bash is useless. And when you start `C:\\Cygwin\\Cygwin.bat` your path is set, but you end up in `$HOME` and not in the right directory.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Install base Cygwin and add the `chere` package. (You might have to start Cygwin once to initialize it, not sure)
2. Add these lines to the Workbench Settings:

```json
// Cygwin, with chere package installed
"terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\Cygwin\\bin\\bash.exe",
"terminal.integrated.shellArgs.windows": ["/bin/xhere", "/bin/bash"],
```

3. Open the terminal in VSCode and see a proper working Cygwin terminal (apart from #7345) appear in the current directory. In doubt type `uname -a`.

So please add the three lines above to https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/integrated-terminal

data.title: Set environment variable before starting a terminal
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Win 10 Pro

Add an option to set environment variables before starting the terminal.
Something like:
```json
"terminal.integrated.envVars.windows": ["DEBUG=1", "LANG=C"],
```
Or maybe you want to split variable and value something like:
```json
"terminal.integrated.envVars.windows": {
    "DEBUG": "1",
    "LANG": "C"
}
```

Obviously the same goes for Linux and Mac

data.title: [css]Error messages will not disappear after the css code in <style> tag is deleted
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.7.1
- OS Version:Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Write something wrong in <style> tag in HTML file, error messages appear.
2. Delete the whole line or whole block of the code
3. Error messages (even color decorators) still exist.
(Error messages won't disappear even the file has been deleted)
![bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19267441/20001664/3d682588-a2b8-11e6-8169-b56a02cd8ea2.PNG)

data.title: Scrolling issue with collapsed code
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0-insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a file with code (ts, html, styl, js, json)
2. Collapse part of the code
3. Use up-arrow key to scroll 

* works normally above collapsed code; 
* below collapsed code cursor jumps down several lines, almost like pressing page-down key...

Someone on gitter mentioned it reproduces with `codei --disable-extensions`.

Worked normally in last insider build.
